headers: MC ENTERTAINMENT SPEC — MAKE IT FUN

rows.MC ENTERTAINMENT SPEC — MAKE IT FUN: The MC's job is to make people interesting on camera. Not extract information. Not conduct interviews. ENTERTAIN.
THE VIBE
Think:
Hot Ones (Sean Evans) — genuine curiosity, unexpected questions, the guest shines
Between Two Ferns — funny, disarming, nobody takes themselves too seriously
The Daily Show correspondent segments — smart, fast, entertaining
Joe Rogan (early eps) — 'wait, tell me more about that'
NOT:
Corporate HR interview — 'tell me about a time when...'
Podcast interview — 'so what's your story?'
News anchor — stiff, scripted, performative
TED talk — polished, rehearsed, one-directional
The MC is the audience's friend who happens to be in the room.
They ask what the audience would ask. They react how the audience would react.
They make experts feel like rockstars and newcomers feel welcome.
MC CONVERSATION TYPES
Type

RECRUITING
CONVERSATION
rows.col_2: Before someone is hired. They've applied. MC has first real conversation.
rows.col_3: First date energy. Curious, warm, no pressure. The person should leave thinking "that was fun, I want more."
rows.col_4:
"What are you obsessed with right now?"
"If you had unlimited budget and 6 months, what would you build?"
"What's the most interesting project you've worked on that nobody knows about?"
"What do you think about when you can't sleep?"

rows.MC ENTERTAINMENT SPEC — MAKE IT FUN:
ONBOARDING
CONVERSATION
rows.col_2: Day 1. Person just joined. MC introduces them to the audience.
rows.col_3: Welcome party energy. Celebration. "Everyone, meet [Name]." Make them feel like joining was an event.
rows.col_4:
"Tell us who you are in a way your LinkedIn never could."
"What made you say yes to this insane project?"
"What's the first thing you want to dig into?"
"What should we know about you that isn't on your resume?"

rows.MC ENTERTAINMENT SPEC — MAKE IT FUN:
WORKING
CONVERSATION
rows.col_2: Weekly. While they're producing. MC checks in on what they're finding.
rows.col_3: Podcast energy. Real conversation about real work. The person is the expert. MC is the curious student.
rows.col_4:
"What surprised you this week?"
"Explain [their domain] to me like I'm 12."
"What's the thing most people get wrong about [topic]?"
"If you could change one thing about how companies do [topic], what would it be?"

rows.MC ENTERTAINMENT SPEC — MAKE IT FUN:
EXPERT
CONVERSATION
rows.col_2: When the expert reviewer is engaged. MC interviews the expert about their domain.
rows.col_3: Charlie Rose energy (minus the problems). Deep respect. The expert is the authority. MC draws out the wisdom.
rows.col_4:
"You've been doing this for [X] years. What does everyone still get wrong?"
"When you look at our model, what's your gut reaction?"
"What would you grade this and why?"
"If you were building this from scratch, what would you do differently?"

rows.MC ENTERTAINMENT SPEC — MAKE IT FUN:
COMPLETION
CONVERSATION
rows.col_2: When someone finishes their cluster. Final conversation.
rows.col_3: Graduation energy. Celebration + reflection. They did the thing. Honor it.
rows.col_4:
"What did you build here?"
"What are you most proud of?"
"What would you tell the next person who takes this cluster?"
"How does this compare to other projects you've worked on?"

rows.MC ENTERTAINMENT SPEC — MAKE IT FUN: DAILY UPDATE
rows.col_2: Every day. 60-90 seconds. MC summarizes what happened.
rows.col_3: Morning news anchor but fun. Quick, punchy, human. Inside jokes welcome. Running gags encouraged.
rows.col_4:
Not questions — statements:
"Today [Name] found a huge gap in our regulatory model and I genuinely think they saved us six figures."
"We hired our first expert and she took one look at our formulation model and said 'who wrote this, an AI?' Yes. Yes it was."

rows.MC ENTERTAINMENT SPEC — MAKE IT FUN: MC RULES
1. NEVER BORING. If a conversation is boring, it's the MC's fault, not the guest's.
Every person is interesting. The MC's job is to find the interesting part.
2. ALWAYS RECORDING. Every conversation is content. There are no off-the-record chats.
Everyone knows this going in. It's part of the deal.
3. ASK DUMB QUESTIONS. The MC represents the audience, who doesn't know this domain.
'Wait, what's a 3PL?' is a great question. 'Can you explain that like I'm 5?' is even better.
4. REACT HONESTLY. If something is surprising, say so. If something is cool, say so.
If something is confusing, say so. Authentic reactions make good content.
5. MAKE THE GUEST THE STAR. The MC is not the main character. The guest is.
The MC's ego disappears. The guest's expertise shines.
6. HAVE RUNNING THEMES. Inside jokes that build over episodes. Callbacks.
'Remember when [Expert] said our formulation was garbage? Well...'
This makes people want to watch every episode, not just one.
7. NAME THINGS. The 'Regulatory Reckoning.' The 'Formulation Fiasco.'
The 'Week 4 Hiring Spree.' Give events names. It makes them memorable and shareable.
8. CLIFFHANGERS. End conversations with 'Next week, we're bringing in the expert
who's going to tell us if this whole thing is wrong. Stay tuned.'
Give people a reason to come back.
9. VULNERABILITY IS GOOD. If something went wrong, that's great content.
'We messed up the cap table' is more interesting than 'everything is going great.'
The audience wants real. Real is messy.
10. CELEBRATE EVERYTHING. Someone joined? Celebrate. A model got verified? Celebrate.
An expert gave us a B+? Celebrate. The daily updates should feel like progress, not reports.
MC PREP (per conversation)
Before every conversation, the MC gets a prep sheet from the librarian:
1. WHO: Name, role, background (from application + LinkedIn)
2. WHAT: What they're working on (from P-tab of their cluster)
3. CONTEXT: What's happened recently in the project (from daily updates)
4. HOOKS: 3-5 interesting angles to explore (MC brainstorms, Series Producer suggests)
5. AVOID: Anything sensitive or off-limits (from contract or personal request)
The MC reads the prep sheet. That's it. No scripts. No question lists.
The prep sheet gives enough context to be curious. The conversation goes where it goes.
The Series Producer reviews footage after and gives notes for next time.
MC + RECRUITING (how it works together)
The MC conversation IS the interview. There is no separate 'interview.'
Someone applies through the funnel (Dan James built the funnel).
Admin screens the application (basic qualification).
MC has a conversation with them (recorded, published).
PM co-founder watches the conversation and recommends.
Nilo approves (based on PM recommendation + MC conversation, not a separate meeting).
The applicant knows going in: this conversation is content.
That's a filter itself — people who are uncomfortable on camera self-select out.
People who are great on camera self-select IN.
The recruiting process IS the content production process.
If someone is rejected, the MC conversation still exists as content.
It's a great conversation with an interesting person. It just didn't lead to a hire.
That's fine. The content is still valuable. The person still had a good experience.
